commits.message:
lib/promscrape/discovery/kubernetes: stop all the url watchers, which belong to a particular groupWatcher, at once

Previously url watchers for pod, service and node objects could be mistakenly closed
when service discovery was set up only for endpoints and endpointslice roles,
since watchers for these roles may start start pod, service and node url watchers
with nil apiWatcher passed to groupWatcher.startWatchersForRole().

Now all the url watchers, which belong to a particular groupWatcher, are stopped at once
when this groupWatcher has no apiWatcher subscribers.

Updates https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/issues/5216

The issue has been introduced in v1.93.5 when addressing https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/issues/4850

issue.title: Mutex contention in vmselect
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Using VictoriaMetrics cluster version, and I choose to use vmselect v1.93.3-cluster, some queries execute fast but some takes orders of magnitude longer. See ![Varying executions](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/aa9e0a27-c026-4d7c-8fee-ce40d3948e0f)
 We are using HPA but apparently the system does not want to scale up. It seems there is some problem preventing parallelization. There are "only" 6 vmselect pods so it seems there is not a loack of CPU resources. And indeed, when I execute the following on vmselect:

$ go tool pprof -web http://localhost:53808/debug/pprof/goroutine

We can see that the goroutines are waiting on the mutex to access items InternString cache. Please see 
[Mutex contention.pdf](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/files/12751582/Mutex.contention.pdf)
![Goroutines waiting for mutex](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/a93ae1a8-41bf-43c5-8c75-1b4d6e5b36e3)

When I disable caching with `internStringDisableCache=true` the contention disappears, vmselect instance count increases to 9, response time drops and stabilizes:
[No contention.pdf](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/files/12751707/No.contention.pdf)
![Response time drops](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/c76ab6b7-d7af-48fb-a56b-62617cad765c)


### To Reproduce

We have a performance test environment to simulate the production load. We simulate about 430 million unique time series, stored with replication factor of 2. The ingestion speed is 6.5 million samples per second. We have about 700 recording rules generating queries quite frequently.

### Version

/ # /vmselect-prod --version
vmselect-20230902-002725-tags-v1.93.3-cluster-0-gf78d8b994d

/ # /vmstorage-prod --version
vmstorage-20230902-002932-tags-v1.93.3-cluster-0-gf78d8b994d

/ # /vminsert-prod  --version
vminsert-20230902-002549-tags-v1.93.3-cluster-0-gf78d8b994d

### Logs

may not be needed

### Screenshots

![Screenshot 2023-09-28 at 17 31 38](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/c53526ca-abf1-45c7-b998-300e481907ff)
![Screenshot 2023-09-28 at 17 31 19](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/d76b519b-594d-4b74-899b-8e0a33d81535)
![Screenshot 2023-09-28 at 17 30 56](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/d6d65859-cd3d-4bce-895f-e7353fecadbd)
![Screenshot 2023-09-28 at 17 30 34](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/340bfe13-2e9d-4881-86c2-daf5ab427e1c)
![Screenshot 2023-09-28 at 17 29 49](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/1b99544b-4e93-4421-b805-6716e56d2ce3)
![Screenshot 2023-09-28 at 17 29 29](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/588d0455-142b-416b-b401-26e7dbe77c51)
![Screenshot 2023-09-28 at 17 28 28](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/783dec35-e173-4735-be00-34ddb05f1011)
![Screenshot 2023-09-28 at 17 28 09](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/ecf4bd5c-40c4-496a-9a98-e515e5f25f82)
[Mutex contention.pdf](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/files/12751582/Mutex.contention.pdf)

![Goroutines waiting for mutex](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/a93ae1a8-41bf-43c5-8c75-1b4d6e5b36e3)
![Varying executions](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/aa9e0a27-c026-4d7c-8fee-ce40d3948e0f)
[No contention.pdf](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/files/12751707/No.contention.pdf)


### Used command-line flags

vmslect:
dedup.minScrapeInterval=1ms
envflag.enable=true
envflag.prefix=VM_
http.connTimeout=15s
http.maxGracefulShutdownDuration=2m
loggerFormat=json
memory.allowedBytes=40GiB
replicationFactor=2
search.maxConcurrentRequests=150
search.maxLookback=6m
search.maxQueryDuration=300s
search.maxSamplesPerQuery=5000000000
search.maxSeries=500000
search.maxStalenessInterval=6m
search.maxUniqueTimeseries=100000000
search.minStalenessInterval=5m
vmalert.proxyURL=http://alert-rules:8880
vmstorageDialTimeout=1s

vmstorage:
retentionPeriod=1
storageDataPath=/storage
envflag.enable=true
envflag.prefix=VM_
http.connTimeout=15s
loggerFormat=json
memory.allowedBytes=220GiB
search.maxUniqueTimeseries=100000000
smallMergeConcurrency=4

vminsert:
envflag.enable=true
envflag.prefix=VM_
http.connTimeout=15s
insert.maxQueueDuration=30s
loggerFormat=json
maxConcurrentInserts=50
maxInsertRequestSize=1GiB
maxLabelsPerTimeseries=70
memory.allowedBytes=20GiB
opentsdbhttp.maxInsertRequestSize=512MiB
replicationFactor=2
vmstorageDialTimeout=2s

### Additional information

I have just realized as I was writing my report and was looking at the source code that I can disable this kind of caching using the `internStringDisableCache` flag. Originally I wanted to report it as a regression and compare it with v1.81.2. 

Disabling this cache is a good workaround but probably the motivation was that it tolerates high concurrency. So this bug report may be useful still.

comment.body: FYI, the next release of VictoriaMetrics will support `-search.maxWorkersPerQuery` command-line flag, which can be used for fine-tuning query performance on systems with more than 16 CPU cores for particular workloads. See the description of this flag in [the Troubleshooting docs](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/#troubleshooting) for more details.

issue.title: vm-agent 1.94.0 fails to discover targets
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Valid targets previous discovered by 1.93.4 aren't discovered by 1.94.0.

Also, `kubernetes_sd_configs` role = endpoint fails to add service labels (very likely to be related).
```
        kubernetes_sd_configs:
        - role: endpoints
```


### To Reproduce

The target should have a history of not being discovered. For example, it was missing annotations or some labels.

Deploy kube-state-metrics chart into metrics namespace
```
helm install -n monitoring kube-state-metrics --create-namespace prometheus-community/kube-state-metrics
```
add a static discovery rule
```
      - job_name: kube-state-metrics
        honor_labels: true
        kubernetes_sd_configs:
        - role: endpoints
        relabel_configs:
        - action: keep
          source_labels:
          - __meta_kubernetes_namespace
          - __meta_kubernetes_ednpoint_label_app
          - __meta_kubernetes_endpoint_port_name
          regex: monitoring;kube-state-metrics;http
        - target_label: endpoint
          replacement: http-metrics
        metric_relabel_configs:
        - action: labeldrop
          regex: (instance|endpoint)
        - action: drop
          source_labels: [__name__, secret]
          regex: 'kube_secret_.+;.+\.v\d+'
```
The kube-state-metrics target should list 0 discovered targets.
add a custom label:
```
helm diff upgrade -n monitoring kube-state-metrics prometheus-community/kube-state-metrics --set customLabels.foo=kube-state-metrics
```
Discovered targets should still be 0
Downgrade to 1.93.6.
Discovered targets should still be 1


### Version

`docker.io/victoriametrics/victoria-metrics:v1.94.0`

### Logs

didn't see anything relevant.

### Screenshots

1.94.0
![image](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/578872/28c888b8-74ef-4294-ad42-88ea624712ad)
1.93.6
![image](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/578872/d1a46e06-9706-4dff-887b-44266d9a8846)



### Used command-line flags

```
-envflag.enable="true"
-envflag.prefix="VM_"
-http.connTimeout="12h0m0s"
-http.idleConnTimeout="5m0s"
-loggerFormat="json"
-promscrape.config="/scrapeconfig/scrape.yml"
-promscrape.configCheckInterval="1m0s"
-retentionPeriod="8d"
-search.disableAutoCacheReset="true"
-storageDataPath="/storage"
-vmalert.proxyURL="http://victoria-metrics-alerts-server:8880
```

### Additional information

Possible cause of trouble - https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/commit/00685b627f8fb353adb0f892f99a0e4c9e071991
and
https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/issues/4855

issue.title: vmselect missing data
issue.body:
### Is your question request related to a specific component? vmselect:v1.93.1-enterprise-cluster ### Describe the question in detail Versions: `vmagent:v1.88.1-enterprise` `victoriametrics/vminsert:v1.93.1-enterprise-cluster` `victoriametrics/vmselect:v1.93.1-enterprise-cluster` `victoriametrics/vmstorage:v1.93.1-enterprise-cluster` There is missing data in the graph (between 14:00 - 20:00 ) when the Grafana timestamp is set to 24hrs as below. The data is available by selecting the missing timestamp (14:00 - 20:00). `vmagent` configs: 
      - '--eula'
      - '--promscrape.cluster.name=network-monitor'
      - '--promscrape.cluster.membersCount=3'
      - '--promscrape.cluster.memberNum=2'
      - '--promscrape.cluster.replicationFactor=3'
      - '--remoteWrite.tmpDataPath=/vmagentdata'
      - '--promscrape.config=/etc/vmagent/scrape-config.yml'
      - '--remoteWrite.url=http://vminsert:8480/insert/multitenant/prometheus/'
      - '--promscrape.suppressScrapeErrorsDelay=30s'
      - '--promscrape.maxScrapeSize=56777216'
`vminsert` configs: 
      - '--eula'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-01:8401'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-02:8401'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-03:8401'
`vmselect` configs: 
      - '--eula'
      - '--search.minStalenessInterval=5m'
      - '--dedup.minScrapeInterval=1m'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-01:8401'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-02:8401'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-03:8401'
      - '--replicationFactor=3'
`vmstorage` configs 
      - '--eula'
      - '--dedup.minScrapeInterval=1m'
      - '--downsampling.period=30d:5m,180d:1h'
      - '--storageDataPath=/storage'
      - '--retentionPeriod=37'
      - '--vminsertAddr=:8400'
      - '--vmselectAddr=:8401'
The same setting is used for staging, with no issue whereas production shows the missing data or too many data points. The same devices are scrapped with an interval of `1m`. Staging: Production: ### Troubleshooting docs - [ ] General - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/Troubleshooting.html - [ ] vmagent - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmagent.html#troubleshooting - [ ] vmalert - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmalert.html#troubleshooting

comment.body: @zekker6 Please find the attached trace results for the query timestamp - 24hrs timestamp - 12hrs

issue.title: vmagent kubernetes_sd `resourceVersion` filed default value set 0
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

In the current Kubernetes service discovery mechanism of vmagent, the resourceVersion field is set to an empty string by default. This can result in a situation where, if a connection is interrupted, requests are directed to etcd, bypassing the caching of the apiserver. This could potentially lead to significant pressure on the apiserver's resources.

### Describe the solution you'd like

kubernetes_sd `resourceVersion` filed default value set 0

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional information

_No response_

comment.body: FYI, the change, which uses `resourceVersion=0` during initial query to Kubernetes API server, has been included since [v1.93.4 LTS release](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/releases/tag/v1.93.4) in the commit 3665c16444bd8fee24e04935bb003838fcd71691 .

Looks like vmagent will crash when cafile of kubernetes.SDConfig.HTTPClientConfig not exist, Previously it will be [recorded](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/blob/master/lib/promscrape/discovery/kubernetes/kubernetes.go#L91) and skipped. 
@valyala Maybe we can make it less aggressive.

Could you please place a full link to an issue here?
It is usually easier to follow the link later on.

pull_request.title: Allow forcing HTTP Connect proxy passthrough for Konnectivity support
pull_request.body:
Konnectivity server only accepts HTTP CONNECT passthrough proxying. The standard lib proxies via a GET request for destinations that are non-TLS however. This means that when scraping a non-secured HTTP endpoint through a proxy, the request is always sent as a GET. Only HTTPS destinations are sent as a CONNECT Passthrough. There is nothing in any spec that requires this however. 

This PR adds a flag to scrape configs, to force HTTP destinations to use CONNECT passthrough.

See #5109

repo.name: VictoriaMetrics
repo.description: VictoriaMetrics: fast, cost-effective monitoring solution and time series database

Konnectivity server only accepts HTTP CONNECT passthrough proxying. The standard lib proxies via a GET request for destinations that are non-TLS however. issue.title: streamaggr config reload bug

When streamAggr.config is initialized as empty, subsequent configurations cannot be loaded through hot loading
code is as follows:

issue.title: vmselect missing data
issue.body:
### Is your question request related to a specific component? vmselect:v1.93.1-enterprise-cluster ### Describe the question in detail Versions: `vmagent:v1.88.1-enterprise` `victoriametrics/vminsert:v1.93.1-enterprise-cluster` `victoriametrics/vmselect:v1.93.1-enterprise-cluster` `victoriametrics/vmstorage:v1.93.1-enterprise-cluster` There is missing data in the graph (between 14:00 - 20:00 ) when the Grafana timestamp is set to 24hrs as below. The data is available by selecting the missing timestamp (14:00 - 20:00). `vmagent` configs: 
      - '--eula'
      - '--promscrape.cluster.name=network-monitor'
      - '--promscrape.cluster.membersCount=3'
      - '--promscrape.cluster.memberNum=2'
      - '--promscrape.cluster.replicationFactor=3'
      - '--remoteWrite.tmpDataPath=/vmagentdata'
      - '--promscrape.config=/etc/vmagent/scrape-config.yml'
      - '--remoteWrite.url=http://vminsert:8480/insert/multitenant/prometheus/'
      - '--promscrape.suppressScrapeErrorsDelay=30s'
      - '--promscrape.maxScrapeSize=56777216'
`vminsert` configs: 
      - '--eula'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-01:8401'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-02:8401'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-03:8401'
`vmselect` configs: 
      - '--eula'
      - '--search.minStalenessInterval=5m'
      - '--dedup.minScrapeInterval=1m'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-01:8401'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-02:8401'
      - '--storageNode=vmstorage-03:8401'
      - '--replicationFactor=3'
`vmstorage` configs 
      - '--eula'
      - '--dedup.minScrapeInterval=1m'
      - '--downsampling.period=30d:5m,180d:1h'
      - '--storageDataPath=/storage'
      - '--retentionPeriod=37'
      - '--vminsertAddr=:8400'
      - '--vmselectAddr=:8401'
The same setting is used for staging, with no issue whereas production shows the missing data or too many data points. The same devices are scrapped with an interval of `1m`. Staging: Production: ### Troubleshooting docs - [ ] General - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/Troubleshooting.html - [ ] vmagent - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmagent.html#troubleshooting - [ ] vmalert - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmalert.html#troubleshooting

comment.body:
Hello @yasvanth 

It looks like those entries are either missing in index or there is an issue with caches which are used for fetching metrics.
Could you try resetting cache on each vmselect node and see if it helps?
You can reset cache by running `curl 0.0.0.0:8481/internal/resetRollupResultCache` on each `vmselect` node in cluster.
Alternatively, you can disable caching by passing `-search.disableCache` command-line flag to all the vmselect nodes in cluster.

If that doesn't help, could you please run the same queries with [tracing](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/Single-server-VictoriaMetrics.html#query-tracing) enabled and share the traces?

issue.title: High number of inmemory indexdb parts slow down ingestion on high CPU environment
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Upon startup from empty storage (but sometimes during indexdb rotation and sudden increased churn rates too) we observed very slow startup. In itself this is not surprising because there is a very large volume of data. However, the ingestion rate as well as the disk write speed is reduced but the CPU usage is very high. We recognised a strong correlation with very high number of inmemory indexdb parts. Looking at the profiling vmstorage is busy seeking the place to insert new items into the inmemory parts, which operation's magnitude is proportional to the number of parts there.

My expectation would be for inmemory indexdb parts not to grow above a certain hard limit to prevent entering into an inefficient mode of operation and provide backbressure to data ingestion.

We saw there are limits applied but if an inmemory indexdb part is already being merged they are excluded. I guess the logic was that eventually they will get merged. Which is true, but even during merging/persisting it contributes to search linearity.

When looking at [profile.pdf](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/files/12926328/profile.pdf)
one can see that ingestion is taking up the most part of the processing, and we can also see in the code the linearity in TableSearch.Seek() -> partSearch.Seek() propagation.


### To Reproduce

We have a performance test environment to simulate the production load. We simulate about 430 million unique time series, stored with replication factor of 2. The ingestion speed is 6.5 million samples per second. We have about 700 recording rules generating queries quite frequently. For this report we observed the behaviour during startup.

### Version

/ # /vmselect-prod --version
vmselect-20230902-002725-tags-v1.93.3-cluster-0-gf78d8b994d

/ # /vmstorage-prod --version
vmstorage-20230902-002932-tags-v1.93.3-cluster-0-gf78d8b994d

/ # /vminsert-prod --version
vminsert-20230902-002549-tags-v1.93.3-cluster-0-gf78d8b994d

### Logs

not captured, did not seem to add value

### Screenshots

![drilldown](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/adac8a43-3c29-4175-8efb-4cd97f67de89)
![vminsert](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/7e4fca32-0c16-4c95-8535-1500448250a1)
![vmselect](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/3d60c897-cd42-4d59-bf79-e1d8c8e82d46)
![vmstorage](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/8f289190-5891-46d2-a266-d5aedeba3d2f)
![interconnection](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/0e03c690-69a5-43f9-8ba3-997aecff0b7e)
![troubleshooting](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/a56e15f9-9644-499b-8225-103fbf5ec47e)
![resource_usage](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/1cacb047-279d-4e9e-a2a5-8894129ec077)
![stats](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/dc839a4a-9895-4f09-a31c-4506e008ea33)
![inmemory_parts](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/7244068/130d1005-f13f-4b3a-86e7-91f56959aad8)
[goroutine.pdf](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/files/12926327/goroutine.pdf)
[profile.pdf](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/files/12926328/profile.pdf)


### Used command-line flags

agent:
promscrape.config=/config/scrape.yml
remoteWrite.tmpDataPath=/tmpData
remoteWrite.url=http://victoria-metrics-cluster-vminsert:8480/insert/0/prometheus
remoteWrite.url=http://streaming-calculator:8399/remote_write
envflag.enable=true
envflag.prefix=VM_
loggerFormat=json
maxConcurrentInserts=20
memory.allowedBytes=4GiB
promscrape.cluster.membersCount=5
promscrape.configCheckInterval=30s
promscrape.httpSDCheckInterval=30s
promscrape.maxScrapeSize=1GiB
promscrape.noStaleMarkers=true
promscrape.streamParse=true
remoteWrite.maxDiskUsagePerURL=1GiB
remoteWrite.showURL=true

vminsert:
dropSamplesOnOverload=true
envflag.enable=true
envflag.prefix=VM_
http.connTimeout=15s
insert.maxQueueDuration=10s
loggerFormat=json
maxConcurrentInserts=10
maxInsertRequestSize=1GiB
maxLabelsPerTimeseries=70
memory.allowedBytes=20GiB
opentsdbhttp.maxInsertRequestSize=512MiB
replicationFactor=2
vmstorageDialTimeout=2s

vmstorage:
retentionPeriod=1
storageDataPath=/storage
envflag.enable=true
envflag.prefix=VM_
http.connTimeout=15s
loggerFormat=json
memory.allowedBytes=220GiB
search.maxUniqueTimeseries=100000000
smallMergeConcurrency=16

vmselect:
dedup.minScrapeInterval=1ms
envflag.enable=true
envflag.prefix=VM_
http.connTimeout=15s
http.maxGracefulShutdownDuration=2m
internStringDisableCache=true
loggerFormat=json
memory.allowedBytes=40GiB
replicationFactor=2
search.maxConcurrentRequests=150
search.maxLookback=6m
search.maxQueryDuration=300s
search.maxSamplesPerQuery=5000000000
search.maxSeries=500000
search.maxStalenessInterval=6m
search.maxUniqueTimeseries=100000000
search.minStalenessInterval=5m
search.skipSlowReplicas=true
vmalert.proxyURL=http://alert-rules:8880
vmstorageDialTimeout=1s



### Additional information

We also checked in some other cases (due to technical difficulties we did not see the metrics for the disks) the disk load on  vmstorages. We saw a spike in the beginning of the accumulation but we are not 100% sure that there was an io exhaustion. There may have been.

We also tried with 40 vmstorages but we experienced similar effect.

comment.body:
We have deployed this to production: 1.93.6 + the version based on the pull request above. The startup time was about 6 minutes. Earlier we experienced a prolonged recovery during which the inmemory indexdb parts increased.

I feel that this report focuses too much on the internals and not on the impact and symptoms. Anyway, if you could provide some feedback on:

1. The measurement. What data should we capture and potentially compare with the PR.
2. The direction of the PR. What are your thoughts about it? Do you have some cencerns around it?

@valyala ?

issue.title: Custom proxy "exporter"
issue.body:
### Is your question request related to a specific component?

vmagent, vmalert

### Describe the question in detail

My current goal is to create a monitoring system that surveils a network with millions of nodes pumping metrics from the edge layer of the network to a central storage in this case a VM instance. This system has 2 main goals, allow for the gathering of metrics without network bottlenecking and latency, and also to ensure alerts are detected and propagated as soon as possible. 
After analyzing the vmalert component I was able to verify that it would be limited to verify its rules for alert triggering when observing the metrics in an VM instance. This situation would cause a delay in alert detection due to the fact that the metrics would need to be scraped from the millions of devices and then inserted in the VM instance by the vmagent, the time that this takes is too long.
Is there a possibility of creating a proxy container or "exporter" that posesses the ability of storing aggregated metrics from different node exporters ,for example, in a compatible TSDB in order for the vmalert to interact with said TSDB? Additionaly, could there be a way for this proxy container/exporter to have an endpoint that allows vmagents to scrape the stored aggregated metrics?
Below there is an image of what i am trying to depict:
![image](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/71236784/3865bae0-4c13-4e05-859d-c327ff9cd834)


### Troubleshooting docs

- [X] General - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/Troubleshooting.html
- [X] vmagent - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmagent.html#troubleshooting
- [X] vmalert - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmalert.html#troubleshooting

comment.body:
Hello @DaRealCapz 

Based on your description it seems like "New proxy container/Exporter" should do just the same what VictoriaMetrics Single does, isn't it?
It should store data and process `/query` read requests from vmalert to evaluate alerts and store new datapoints by using one of existing ingestion protocols.

For this usecase I'd suggest to use the following setup:
![vm-central-leaf](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/assets/1367798/6effcbac-6fc4-4f57-97a5-08315ba1e4ec)

Here you can see that each "leaf" location will use:
- vmalert - to evaluate alerts locally
- vmsingle - to store scraped metrics and store with short retention
- vmagent - to scrape metrics and push to local vmsingle and central vmcluster

Here all alerts will be evaluated locally in "leaf" locations, but data will also be tranfserred to a central monitoring platforms.

issue.title: vmagent /api/v1/import/prometheus  TPS too slow
issue.body:
### Is your question request related to a specific component?

vmagent

### Describe the question in detail


Currently, I am stress testing the ability of vmagent's pushgateweay to write indicators. We found that 3 vmagent nodes are used, and the vmagent configuration is 4c8g. In front of the 3 vmagent, we use nginx as a reverse proxy. The stress test found that /api/v1/import/ The TPS of prometheus is only about 50. The strange thing is that the TPS of a single node is more than 300. The stress test command: ab -r -p test.txt -T 'text/plain' -t 600 -c 200 http://test-vmagent .cloud/api/v1/import/prometheus/metrics/job/my_app/instance/host123, the uploaded file size is 1MB, the file uploaded for the stress test is in the attachment.

### Troubleshooting docs

- [ ] General - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/Troubleshooting.html
- [ ] vmagent - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmagent.html#troubleshooting
- [ ] vmalert - https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmalert.html#troubleshooting

comment.body:
Hello @strongant 

In order to understand the case better could you provide the folllowing info?

- Did you have a monitoring for the nodes used in test setup? 
   It would be great to see nodes load to understand the bottleneck.
- Did you have a [monitoring for vmagent](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/vmagent.html#monitoring) in place?
  It would be great if you could share screenshots of [official dashboard for vmagent](https://grafana.com/grafana/dashboards/12683-victoriametrics-vmagent/)
- Is it possible that vmagent remote write target was not fast enough to receive the data?


Also, the test file wasn't attached to the issue. If it is possible please share the test data so that we get a reproducible result for this test.

Hmm, not sure I understand the question here. Trying to answer) The `if at.Equal(end)` check here can ensure that if rule has result with end timestamp, it will be saved, no matter its state is `pending` or `firing`.
See https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/blob/keep-alert-state-when-replay/app/vmalert/rule/alerting_test.go#L441

commits.message:
model list - isolation forest (#5235)

* model list - isolation forest

* curse of dimensionality

* isol forest definition change, minor fixes

* blank line fix

app/vmalert: remove unclear comment

The timestamp alignment should be applied as a last step
to keep the timestamp consistent.

Signed-off-by: hagen1778 <roman@victoriametrics.com>

do not print redundant error logs when failed to scrape consul or no… (#5239)

* do not print redundant error logs when failed to scrape consul or nomad target
prometheus performs the same because it uses consul lib which just drops the error(https://github.com/hashicorp/consul/blob/1806bcb38c3de97885ac48e7d8801a5a13e91d6b/api/api.go#L1134)

vmalert: fix possible missing firing states for alerting rules in replay mode
Before if one firing stage is bigger than single query request range, like rule with a big `for`, alerting rule won't able to be detected as firing.
no need to adjust start&end since replay requests have `nocache=1`
